DOC.HEAD: Police Free Hostages Held By Prisoners, Kill Five Criminals
DOC.TEXT: Police stormed a cell block controlled by drug traffickers holding 18 hostages, and six traffickers were killed and five hostages wounded, authorities said today. Police late Monday gained the release of all of the hostages, including two children, and the situation at the La Picota jail in southern Bogota had returned to normal, a Justice Department spokesman said. The spokesman asked not to be identified so he would not become the target of revenge by any of the prisoners involved. The rescue came after two days of fruitless negotiations with the prisoners, who had taken the hostages after a failed jailbreak Sunday. The prisoners subdued guards during visiting hours at the jail and were putting on their uniforms in an attempt to escape, Bogota's El Tiempo newspaper reported today. The paper, quoting prison sources, said authorities discovered the plan and sealed off the cell block before the prisoners, all held on drug trafficking charges, could flee. The trapped criminals then took hostages, including some civilians who had been visiting their jailed family members, and made a series of protests and demands, El Tiempo reported. The paper said the prisoners began by protesting the death of Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha, the trafficker of the Medellin cartel who was killed Dec. 15 in a gunfight with police on Colombia's northern coast. The prisoners said they would release the hostages only if the administration of President Virgilio Barco agreed to end its extradition of drug traffickers to the United States, El Tiempo said. The administration has extradited 11 drug suspects since August when it decreed the policy. The prisoners also demanded a meeting with the Colombian Justice Minister, Roberto Salazar and other officials. They said that they wanted to be transferred to another, less crowded jail, El Tiempo reported. The Justice Ministry official reached by telephone said he could not confirm the details of the takeover.
